B.H. Roberts (1904) responds to an Iowa attorney's objection about KJV language in the Book of Mormon. Argues Joseph Smith adopted KJV phrasing for parallel passages where substance matched but diverged where the Nephite original was superior — especially KJV translators' italic supplied words. Includes extensive verse-by-verse comparison tables (Isaiah/KJV/BOM and Matt 5–7 vs 3 Nephi 12–14 vs Douay Bible). Also argues Urim and Thummim translation was not mechanical but required exhausting intellectual and spiritual effort. One of the earliest published defenses (1904) of KJV language in the BoM — demonstrates this objection has been addressed for over a century.
Skousen (1994) — Original Language of the BoM: Upstate New York Dialect, King James English, or Hebrew? JBMS 3/1. Analyzes whether BoM English derives from KJV, dialect, or Hebrew patterns.

Spencer (2020) — Missing Words: KJV Italics, the Translation of the BoM, and Joseph Smith as an Unlearned Reader. Interpreter 38. Directly addresses the 'Joseph copied from the KJV' claim by analyzing handling of italic supplied words.
